tei:div.tei:ab: neu: Beethoven Eroica-Variationen; nach Tunlichkeit genau mit Fingersatz u. Vortrag. Mozart, Sonate Adur mit Variationen u. alla turca.
new: Beethoven "Eroica" Variations; as far as possible precise, with fingering and performance. Mozart, Sonate Adur with variations and alla turca.

op. 111, flüchtig. Brahms: ungarischen Tanz Fis-moll; Chopin: Etude F-dur; Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll; Einiges aus der Mondschein-Sonate,Schenker prepared a facsimile edition of this sonata during the 1920/21 saison. According to his diary, he dictated the commentary between 12 November and 6 December 1920. 1 Satz; Sonate Fmoll op. 2 No 1, letzten Satz, Linie. Chopin: Walzer Des-dur, Ges-dur, F-dur, As-dur; Schubert: Rondo A-dur. Schumann: Traumeswirren. Scarlatti:
Stücke in D-moll, D-dur. Beethoven: Waldstein-Sonate. —

Op. 111, cursorily; Brahms: Hungarian Dance in F minor; Chopin: Etude in F major; Beethoven: Sonata in D minor; some points in the "Moonlight" Sonata, first movement; Sonata in F minor, Op. 2, No. 1, last movement, line. Chopin: Waltzes in D major, G major, F major, A major; Schubert: Rondo in A major. Schumann, "Traumes Wirren." Scarlatti:
pieces in D minor, D major. Beethoven: "Waldstein" Sonata. —

Diabelli-Variationen fortgesetzt; Beethoven: Bagatellen neu: F-dur, As-dur, A-dur, Bdur, Ddur. Scarlatti: Dm, D-dur. wiederholt Beethoven Bagatelle C-m, op. 101, 1. Satz. Händel-Variationen; Chopin: Preludes Des-dur, die Wiederholungen auswendig. —

Theorie: zweistimmige Fuge nach Nottebohm (Fortsetzung),Probably a reference to Gustav Nottebohm, Beethovens Studien, vol. I: Beethoven's Unterricht bei J. Haydn, Albrechtsberger und Salieri (Leipzig: Rieter-Biedermann, 1873). The section on two-voiced fugue is on pp. 70‒88. This source is mentioned in the 1919/20 lessonbook in connection with Figdor but not Elias. Bellermann, Marx. Wohltemp. Klavier Bd. I: Dux u. Comes-Studien. Linien-Studien.

Für Frl. Kahn Sonate op. 31 No 3. — Chopin: Etude Fdur aufgeschrieben; Brahms: Walzer No 4 für Frl. Kahn u. Toccata Dmoll. Chopin: Walzer As-dur. Mozart: Sonate C-dur. Verschiedenes: Brahms: I Sinfonie (Furtwängler-
Konzert).This may be relevant: Schenker's diary, May 13, 1921: "In the Tonkünstler-Verein I place a reservation for the Furtwängler concerts." Schumann: Traumeswirren, Des-dur-Stelle. —

Diabelli Variations continued; Beethoven: Bagatelles new: F major, A major, A major, B major, D major. Scarlatti: D minor, D major. Repeated: Beethoven: Bagatelle in C minor; Op. 101, first movement. Brahms Handel Variations; Chopin: Prelude in D major, the repetitions from memory. —
Theory: two-voiced fugue according to Nottebohm (continuation), Bellermann, Marx. Well-Tempered Clavier Book I: study of dux and comes. Study of lines.

For Miss Kahn Sonata Op. 31, No. 3. — Chopin: Etude in F major analysis written out; Brahms: Waltz No. 4 for Miss Kahn and Toccata in D minor. Chopin: Waltz in A major. Mozart: Sonata in C major. Miscellaneous: Brahms: First Symphony (Furtwängler
concert). Schumann: "Traumes Wirren," D-major section. —

Analysen: Brahms Fis-moll-IntermezzoThere is no F minor Intermezzo by Brahms. Most likely he is referring to that in F minor, Op. 118, No. 4, or perhaps the Capriccio in F minor, Op. 76, No. 1.; Beethoven: op. 2 No 1, op. 59 No 1, Scherzo, Form u. Linie; 1. Satz ebenfalls Linie. Ehrenvoll nachträglich gefragt, nachdem er im Seminar seine Vorlesung schon gehalten hat.Schenker's diary for February 9, 1921 reports: "Klammerth tells us about Figdor's approach in his seminar, which is incomprehensible." Klammerth was attending Guido Adler's seminar at the Musikhistorisches Institut in the University of Vienna around this time, and this raises the possibility that Figdor was, too. Op. 53. Scarlatti Dmoll. Ein wenig gespielt, bloß Beethoven op. 2 No 1 u. op. 53.Schenker's diary for May 31, 1921 has: "Figdor is bailing out; with only 10,000 Kronen a month, expenditure of this kind is not possible."

Analyses: Brahms Intermezzo in F minor; Beethoven: Op. 2, No. 1; Op. 59, No. 1, Scherzo, form and line; the line in the first movement as well. Honorably asked questions in retrospect, after his lecture in the seminar had already taken place. Op. 53. Scarlatti D minor. Played only a little, merely Beethoven Op. 2, No. 1 and Op. 53.

tei:head.tei:note: Schenker's diary for September 1, 1920 records: "To Miss Fried (letter): I agree to three lessons"; November 27, 1920 reports: "Fried asks for two lessons [a week]; I reprimand her; in response she will ask her father"; November 29: "Fried books three lessons."

tei:div.tei:ab: Kontrapunkt. Haydn: Divertimento Fmoll. Chopin: Etude Fdur, Edur. Beethoven: Bagatellen op. 119 B-dur, Ddur, Asdur, Fdur. Chopin: Etude Cismoll. Sonate op. 2 No 3. Wiederholt Mozart: Sonate Adur.

Counterpoint. Haydn: Divertimento in F minor. Chopin: Etudes in F major, E major. Beethoven: Bagatelles Op. 119 in B major, D major, A major, F major. Chopin: Etude in C minor. Sonata Op. 2, No. 3. Revisited Mozart: Sonata in A major.

Konzertprogramm,Hupka played an all-Beethoven concert in the Mozart-Saal of the Wiener Konzerthaus on December 16, 1920. According to the digital archive of the Konzerthaus, the program included the Sonatas Op. 27, No. 2, Op. 81a, and Op. 101 as well as six Bagatelles and the Rondo a capriccio Op. 129 (“Rage over a Lost Penny”). Schenker’s diary describes a rehearsal at the Konzertsaal on December 14 in which Hupka says he will be repeating the concert in the Großer Saal, which seats over 1,800, and on December 30 invites Schenker to the rehearsal there. The Konzerthaus archive has no record of the latter event, but Schenker’s diary does mention another rehearsal by Hupka at the Konzerthaus on January 7, 1921. He also gave a recital in Berlin c. February 13 and apparently in Munich c. March 3. dazu verschiedene kleine Stücke als Nummern künftiger Programme, z.B. Mendelssohn: Gondellied Gm
No 46Here Schenker seemingly conflates two of Mendelssohn’s Songs Without Words, namely No. 6 ("Gondellied") and No. 46, both of which are in G minor. The latter piece is not a barcarolle. A copy of Mendelssohn's Songs without Words from the Schenker Nachlass (OC score/79) contains annotations for performance and harmonic analysis in both pieces.; Chopin: Mazurken Am, Hm; Bach Präludium Esmoll.Schenker had written an article on this piece the previous spring for the first issue of Der Tonwille. According to his diary, he received the page-proofs for this article on September 27, 1920, a few days before the beginning of the 1920/21 saison. Haydn: Menuett aus den Esdur Sonate. Chopin: Walzer Gesdur, Fdur, Des-dur. Schumann: Vogel als Prophet usw.

Concert program, with various small pieces as numbers for future programs, e.g. Mendelssohn: Gondola Song in G minor
No. 46; Chopin: Mazurkas in A minor, B minor; Bach Prelude in E minor. Haydn: Minuet from the Sonata in E major. Chopin: Waltzes in G major, F major, D major. Schumann: "Vogel als Prophet," etc.

tei:div.tei:note: Jeanette Schenker writes these notes continuously, in a single paragraph.
tei:div.tei:ab: Beethoven: Sonate op. 31 No 1, No 2, op. 7. Schumann: „Des Abends“, „Warum“, Traumeswirren. Chopin: Nocturne Fdur, Dmoll.There is no Nocturne in D minor (Dmoll). Most likely, that in B minor (Bmoll), Op. 9, No. 1 is intended, since Schenker taught the latter several times.

Wiederholt Chopin: Préludes Desdur, Fis-dur. Mondscheinsonate.Schenker prepared a facsimile edition of this sonata during the 1920/21 saison. According to his diary, he dictated the commentary between 12 November and 6 December 1920. Chopin: Walzer Desdur, Prélude Cdur. Beethoven: Sonate Fdur op. 10, letzter Satz. op. 110, 111, 106, 109. Brahms-Paganini-Variationen. Stellen aus Chopin Etudes.

Theoretische Fragen: Bach: 1. Bdur Präludium; Beethoven: op. 53, 1. Satz, Durchführung, Coda. Chopin: Etude Ges-dur Stufen u. dgl. Bach: Toccata u. Fuge Dm.Either the Toccata and Fugue in D minor for Organ, BWV 565, of which transcriptions for piano existed by Tausig, Busoni, Reger, and others; or the first two movements of the Toccata in D minor for harpsichord, BWV 913. Durch Elias s.o.In the notes for Elias's lessons, Elias twice plays "for Miss Kahn": Beethoven Op. 31 No. 3 and Brahms Waltz No. 4; and after the latter there appears the Toccata in D minor, BWV 913.

tei:div.tei:note: Jeanette Schenker writes these notes continuously, in a single paragraph.
tei:div.tei:ab: Beethoven: Sonata Op. 31, No. 1, No. 2, Op. 7. Schumann: "Des Abends," "Warum," "Traumes Wirren." Chopin: Nocturnes in F major, D minor.

Revisited: Chopin: Preludes in D major, F major. "Moonlight" Sonata. Chopin: Waltz in D major, Prelude in C major. Beethoven: Sonata in F major, Op. 10, last movement. Opp. 110, 111, 106, 109. Brahms Paganini Variations. Passages from Chopin Etudes.

Theoretical questions: Bach: first Prelude in B major; Beethoven: Op. 53, first movement, development, coda. Chopin: Etude in G major, scale steps and so forth. Bach: Toccata and Fugue in D minor. On lessons with Elias, see above.

Exposition der Fuge nach Marx u. Wohltemp. Klavier.Cf. Schenker's diary October 27, 1920: "Klammerth to first lesson (fugue)." Eigene Versuche. Choral: „Ach Gott, siehe vom Himmel“ "Ach Gott, vom Himmel sieh darein" (Beiträge zur Seminari.e. Guido Adler's seminar at the Musikhistorisches Institut, Vienna University. See also reference in notes for Figdor. The chorale is BWV 2/6 or BWV 77/6, Riemenschneider 262 or 253.-Prüfung). Einiges aus dem Generalbaß nach Seb. Bach.J.S. Bach's Precepts and Principles for Playing the Thorough-Bass or Accompanying in Four Parts, trans. Pamela Poulin, with facsimile of the manuscript (Oxford: Clarendon, 1994). See also Hedi Siegel, A Source for Schenker's Study of Thorough-Bass: His Annotated Copy of J. S. Bach's Generalbassbüchlein, in Schenker Studies (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1990), pp. 15–28. Stellen aus den Leonoren-Ouverturen, Durchführung. Beethoven: Diabelli-Variationen 15. Appassionata. Chopin: Walzer Desd.

Fugal exposition according to Marx and the Well-tempered Clavier. His own attempts. Chorale: "Ach Gott, siehe vom Himmel" "Ach Gott, vom Himmel sieh darein" (submissions for the seminar examination). Some passages from J. S. Bach's Generalbassbüchlein. Excerpts from the "Leonore" Overtures, development. Beethoven: Diabelli Variations, No. 15. "Appassionata" Sonata. Chopin: Waltz in D major.

Zweistimmiger Kontrapunkt abgeschlossen. Em. Bach: Sonate Adur, Gdur, Cdur.Schenker's edition of C. P. E. Bach sonatas includes two in G major (W 55/6 and 56/2), one in C major (W 55/1), but none in A major. Beethoven: Klavierkonzert Gdur.
Two-voiced counterpoint completed. C. P. E. Bach: Sonatas in A major, G major, C major. Beethoven: Piano Concerto in G major.

Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll. Bach: Chromatische Phantasie. Chopin: Etude Cismoll. Form, Wiederholt Schumann: „Des Abends.“ Brahms: Intermezzo Cism. Beethoven: Mondschein-Sonate. Schenker prepared a facsimile edition of this sonata during the 1920/21 saison. According to his diary, he dictated the commentary between November 12 and December 6, 1920. —
Beethoven: Sonata in D minor. Bach: Chromatic Fantasy. Chopin: Etude in C minor. Form, Revisited Schumann: "Des Abends." Brahms: Intermezzo in C minor. Beethoven: "Moonlight" Sonata. —

Kontrapunkt. Bach: Violin-Konzert Cdur, Form, Stufen (für SchifferThe violinist Herr Schiffer is mentioned several times in Schenker's diary, in conjunction with Frau Pairamall, between April 1919 and February 1923 and again in June 1932 (e.g. Schenker's diary, January 17, 1921: "Pairamall ... will come with Schiffer"; January 24, 1921: "Pairamall with Schiffer ...").). Wiederholt:
Chopin: Etüden Gismoll, Emoll, Fdur, Cdur, Fmoll, Gisdur.There is no Etude in G major. Intended may be the Etude in G major (Gesdur), Op. 10, No. 5 or Op. 25, No. 9, or the Etude in G minor (Gismoll), Op. 25, No. 6. Mit Schiffer wiederholt Beethoven: Klavier-Violin-Sonaten Cmoll, Amoll. Brahms: Sonate Dmoll. Bach: Cmoll-Phantasie.Perhaps the Sonata in C minor for violin and harpsichord, BWV 1017, or the Fantasy in C minor for keyboard, BWV 906. Mozart: Klavier-Violin-Sonate Bdur. Beethoven: Klavier-Violin-Sonaten Fdur, Gdur No 7 u. G-dur letzte.

Counterpoint. Bach: Violin Concerto in C major, form, scale steps (for Schiffer). Revisited:
Chopin: Etudes in G minor, E minor, F major, C major, F minor, G major. Revisited with Schiffer Beethoven: Sonatas for Violin and Piano in C minor, A minor. Brahms: Sonata in D minor. Bach: C-minor Fantasy. Mozart: Sonata for Violin and Piano in B major. Beethoven: Sonatas for Violin and Piano in F major, G major No. 7, and the last G major.

Wiederholt Beethoven: Sonate Dmoll, 1. Satz, Analyse befestigt. Schubert: Sonate Gdur (erst am 21. I. Wiederholung der Beethoven Sonate abgeschlossen). Schumann: „Des Abends“. Brahms: Rhapsodie Gmoll. Schumann: „Traumeswirren“, „Aufschwung“, „In der Nacht“, „Warum?“.

Revisited Beethoven: Sonata in D minor, first movement, analysis reinforced. Schubert: Sonata in G major (review of the Beethoven sonata completed only on January 21). Schumann: "Des Abends." Brahms: Rhapsody in G minor. Schumann: "Traumes Wirren," "Aufschwung," "In der Nacht," "Warum?".

Mozart: Sonate Adur. Beethoven: Bagatellen Fdur. Beethoven: op. 2 No 2.
Bach: Chromatische Phantasie.

Mozart: Sonata in A major. Beethoven: Bagatelle in F major. Beethoven: Op. 2, No. 2.
Bach: Chromatic Fantasy.
Appassionata begonnen. Spielt mir Brahms Fmoll-Sonate vor. Geht ab.Cf. Schenker's diary, December 31, 1920: "Volk nimmt Abschied, geht zu Weisse." ("Volk bids farewell, is going to Weisse.") —
"Appassionata" Sonata begun. Plays Brahms Sonata in F minor for me. Leaves.

Lieder von Beethoven, Schumann.Schenker's diary records on November 5: "Nach Tisch zu Gärtner; übergebe die Raucherkarte; er bittet mich, die Begleitung zu einigen Liedern vorspielen zu dürfen; setze Mittwoch abends fest." ("After lunch to Gärtner; give him the tobacco ration card; he asks me for permission to play the accompaniment of a few songs; schedule for Wednesday evening."); November 10: "Gärtner mit Liedern zwischen 6–7h." ("Gärtner with songs between 6:00 and 7:00."); November 17: "Gärtner zum zweitenmal, bringt die Tabakfassung mit." ("Gärtner for the second time, brings along the tobacco ration form.") —
Songs by Beethoven, Schumann. —
